Text hex logos with {hext}

hext
r
Author

Matt Dray

Published

February 15, 2026

  ________
 /        \
/    ⬡⬢    \
\   hext   /
 \________/

tl;dr

The {hext} R package helps you make text-based hex logos.

A simple mind

Call me a normie, but I am an R-hex-logo enjoyer.

I took a step further last year to create my own (limited) hex-making package, {gex}, which I’ve written about before1.

The goal of {gex} was to keep things simple: minimal dependencies, only grid graphics2.

But I was too short-sighted. I went simple, but not simple enough.

Big-brain simple minds

It took Yihui’s return to blogging to remind me about the beauty of simplicity.

His recent post struck a chord: bye, hex stickers. In particular, he made an entirely text-based hex logo for {litedown}, with Charlie Gao’s {secretbase}3 also joining the text revolution.

The spirit of {litedown} and {secretbase} is simplicity. Their logos match this aesthetic.

I feel like simplicity is a good goal in general.

So, naturally, I have overengineered a simple thing to make it simple for you to not think about the complication behind such a simple thing.

Next: text hext

{hext} lets you write text-based logos.

You could install like:

pak::pak("matt-dray/hext")  # GitHub-only

There is only one function: hext(). (This is a feature, not a bug.)

Hexes have four lines4 to which you can add text and specify alignment.

hext::hext(
  "keep", "it", "simple,", "silly",
  "left", "centre", "right", "left"
)
  ________
 /keep    \
/    it    \
\   simple,/
 \silly___/

hext() handles character padding and line-length limits on your behalf. It tries its best with Unicode (like emoji), but rendering is hard.

Hexagone

That’s it, really.

Think less, say less.

  2. The irony being that the original iteration—called {hexbase}—was even simpler. Dependency-free, in fact.↩︎
